fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Engineering Physics is offered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. The program is designed to provide a broad foundation in physics and engineering principles, as well as a strong background in mathematics and computational methods. The curriculum includes coursework in mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, and quantum mechanics, as well as courses in electrical and computer engineering.
shortProgramDescription: The Engineering Physics B.S. program provides a strong foundation in physics and engineering principles, preparing students for careers in research, development, and industry.
classHighlights: The program begins with foundational courses in physics, including Mechanics (PHYS2A or2B), Electricity and Magnetism (PHYS2C or2D), and Thermodynamics (PHYS105A).
Students also complete a series of mathematics courses, including Calculus (MATH20A,20B,20C, and20D) and Differential Equations (MATH20E or21C).
Electrical and Computer Engineering coursework includes Introduction to ECE (ECE1), Circuit Analysis (ECE101), and Electronics (ECE65).
Additional required courses cover topics such as computational methods, programming, and engineering design.
Upper-division physics courses provide in-depth coverage of topics like quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, and electromagnetic theory.
Students also complete a series of technical electives in ECE or other approved departments.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental principles of physics and engineering to solve complex problems.
Demonstrate a strong understanding of mathematical and computational methods.
Analyze and design electrical and computer engineering systems.
Work effectively in teams to solve engineering problems.
Apply principles of physics to engineering design and development.
additionalInformation: Students must satisfy major, college, and university requirements. The program is designed to be completed in four years, with careful planning and advising.
